title: Lowe searches for breathing room on inflation target
text:
However Warren Hogan, an independent economist who is an adjunct professor at UTS Business School, said that if the inflation target band of 2 to 3 per cent had been adjusted to 1 to 3 per cent as it is in Canada and Norway, than the central bank would not be subject to any pressures to cut rates, either political or otherwise.

"We would definitely not have had to cut if the inflation target was between 1 and 3 per cent instead of 2 to 3 per cent," Professor Hogan said.

"The two most similar economies to ours – Canada and Norway – both have 1 to 3 per cent target bands. This has been much more consistent with global inflation and yet provides the flexibility as well."

QIC chief economist Matthew Peter said the central bank's original mandate to achieve the inflation target was protected by independence.

"In the 1980s, they had a mandate from the government to tackle inflation even though it meant you were going to slow the economy down.

"It was important they had the independence because they were going to make decisions that weren't positive in other aspects of the economy. I don't see it's any difference today."

This means that the question the Reserve Bank board has been asking itself when making interest rate decisions is how those decisions can best contribute to the welfare of the Australian people.

On Tuesday Dr Lowe mentioned that his board had considered concerns about how persistently low inflation could hurt people.

"It is possible that, in some circumstances, a low and stable inflation environment provides fertile ground for the emergence of some financial stability risks.

"As we have seen too often, the crystallisation of these risks can have very large welfare consequences, with people losing their jobs, their incomes and their savings."

But Westpac's Bill Evans said the key management task for Dr Lowe was people's expectations.

"What they don’t want is inflation expectations to fall. It’s a matter of managing expectations and therefore you need to be seen to be doing something next year if you're still well below your target.

"If you do nothing people think you've accepted a lower profile."
description: If Australia treated inflation the same way our most similar economies of Canada and Norway did then the Reserve Bank may not have had to cut interest rates three times this year.
